Counting Crows are 'Somewhere Under Wonderland'

Counting Crows will perform 'Somewhere Under Wonderland' at the Louisville Palace

Counting Crows are 'Somewhere Under Wonderland'

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 9:37 a.m. EST December 3, 2014

The Counting Crows will perform Dec. 10 at the Louisville Palace.(Photo: Danny Clinch 08)

Story Highlights

  • Counting Crows perform at the Louisville Palace Dec. 10 in support of a new album.
  • "Somewhere Under Wonderland" is the band's first album of original material in six years.
  • "August and Everything After," Counting Crows' debut album, has sold around 10 million copies.
  • Lexington-based artist Felipe Molina painted the cover of "Somewhere Under Wonderland."
CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Inspiration for songwriters can come from a myriad of directions. Maybe you stumble across a forgotten book given you by an ex-lover, or an overheard conversation sparks a story.

Adam Duritz, singer and primary songwriter for Counting Crows, has never had to look far for material. Intense self-examination is the norm for Duritz, who for two decades has written almost exclusively about his life and frequently tangled emotions

But that changed with the band's latest album, "Somewhere Under Wonderland," and the motor-mouthed Duritz is pretty jacked up about the results. The band performs Wednesday at the Louisville Palace.

"Somewhere Under Wonderland" is Counting Crows' first album of original material in six years. In the interim Duritz wrote songs for a play, "Black Sun," and the band recorded an album of cover songs, "Underwater Sunshine (Or What We Did On Our Summer Vacation)."

COURIER-JOURNAL

With Counting Crows on its way, Jeffrey Lee Puckett looks at the best-selling rock albums of the 1990s.

That combination of writing for characters other than himself, and exclusively singing lyrics he didn't write, fundamentally changed the way he approached "Somewhere Under Wonderland." It's the first Counting Crows album populated by fictional characters, even if the emotions are familiar.

"For me, the important thing about a song isn't that it's a story about my life," Duritz said. "What you're trying to communicate is something that you feel, some emotional thing. For most of my life I've done that by telling semi-autobiographical stories, and I felt kind of in a rut with that, honestly.

"I can see why people would get bored with that story because if you watch it for a while it doesn't go anywhere, because most people's lives don't, but when I wrote for the play I realized that I could communicate about things that I feel really deeply about ... and do it in a song that has nothing to do with my day."

“Somewhere Under Wonderland” is the new album by Counting Crows.(Photo: Promotional photo)

Counting Crows fans have been consistently absorbed by Duritz's life since 1993, when the band's debut album, "August and Everything After," was released. The band was unknown outside of California's Bay Area, but the album exploded out of the gate thanks to a hit single, "Mr. Jones," and quickly sold millions, eventually selling around 10 million copies.

Duritz and guitarist David Bryson are the founding members, having started as a duo in 1991, but Charlie Gillingham and David Immerglück have been in the band nearly as long. Dan Vickrey, Jim Bogios and Millard Powers round out the band, which has retained a signature sound — traditional rock with a headstrong flair for the dramatic.

Duritz said that the band has never released a record over which it didn't have complete control.

"We were always free to just follow whatever sort of artistic or creative vibe that we wanted to run down," he said, "and the nice thing about that is that every record has the same sort of feel as the first one, in a way, because it's just us making records that we want to make."

"August and Everything After" remains a touchstone for the band's fans — a live version was released in 2011 — but Counting Crows is far from a nostalgia act rehashing its glory days. The band has released six studio albums of original songs, and "Somewhere Under Wonderland" earned the band some of its best reviews.

Duritz said that band members consistently "beat the hell out of each other" when making records, knowing that they have to stand as lasting documents. They wrote "Somewhere Under Wonderland" more collaboratively than usual, meeting at Duritz's house three times last September and October to write and then quickly recorded it a month later.

Adam Duritz is the lead singer and primary songwriter for Counting Crows.(Photo: Promotional)

The album was released this September, capping nearly two years of non-stop creativity and increasingly tight live shows. Duritz said that the band has been performing at its peak, just in time for a long run of "Somewhere Under Wonderland" tour dates.

"We had a great tour this summer," he said. "The record wasn't out, but we were playing all of the songs anyway because we wanted to get good at playing them before it was time to tour the record.

"The first time we toured the record was just recently, in Europe, and it was awesome. It was amazing. Of the nine songs on the record, we played seven or eight every night. It's a lot to play seven or eight songs from a new record, and it could be problematic, but it hasn't been."

Jeffrey Lee Puckett can be reached at (502) 582-4160, jpuckett@courier-journal.com and on Twitter, @JLeePuckett.

COUNTING CROWS, TWIN FORKS

WHEN: 7:30 p.m. Wednesday

WHERE: Louisville Palace, 625 S. Fourth St.

COST: $29.50, $39.50, $45, $55, $85, available at the box office, online at www.louisvillepalace.com and www.ticketmaster.com, and by phone at (800) 745-3000.

COVER ARTIST

Artist Felipe Molina, a New York native now living in Lexington, has been Counting Crows' cover artist for a decade. He also made a painting for each song on "Somewhere Under Wonderland."

"The first purchase I ever made as a guy who made money because he sold some records, was I bought some paintings by this guy, like, 20 years ago," Adam Duritz said. "I really loved them, and for this record we had him paint a different thing for every song. He'll be at the show."
